definitions.definition: to make somebody/something seem less bad

examples.text: The excellent acting wasn't enough to redeem a weak plot.
The only **redeeming feature** of the job *(= good thing about it)* is the salary.
She seems to have no redeeming qualities *(= good aspects of her character)* at all.
In an attempt to redeem the situation, Jed offered to help sell tickets.

definitions.definition: to do something to improve the opinion that people have of you, especially after you have done something bad

examples.text: He has a chance to redeem himself after last week's mistakes.

definitions.definition: to save somebody from the power of evil

examples.text: Christians believe that Jesus Christ came to redeem us from sin.
He knew he was a sinner, redeemed by the grace of God.

definitions.definition: to pay the full sum of money that you owe somebody; to pay a debt
to exchange something such as shares or vouchers for money or goods

examples.text: This voucher can be redeemed at any of our branches.

definitions.definition: to get back a valuable object from somebody by paying them back the money you borrowed from them in exchange for the object

examples.text: He was able to redeem his watch from the pawnshop.

definitions.definition: to do what you have promised that you will do

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘buy back’): from Old French redimer or Latin redimere, from re- ‘back’ + emere ‘buy’.
